name: MERCURY
details: Discovered in ancient times, no specific discovery date.
Recorded in Babylonian texts around 3000 BC.
Diameter: about 4,880 km.
Surface area: about 74 million km².
Mass: about 3.30 × 10²³ kg.
Has a very thin atmosphere mainly consisting of oxygen, sodium, hydrogen, helium, and potassium.
Average distance from the Sun: about 57.91 million km.
Average distance from Earth: about 91 million km (varies based on the positions of the two planets in orbit).
Smallest planet in the Solar System and closest to the Sun.
Surface has many craters and no water, causing daytime temperatures to reach up to 430°C, while nighttime temperatures can drop to -180°C.
Orbits the Sun in 88 Earth days and rotates on its axis in about 59 Earth days.
No natural satellites.

name: VENUS
details: Known since ancient times, no specific discovery date.
Often called the 'Evening Star' due to its bright light.
Diameter: about 12,104 km.
Surface area: about 460 million km².
Mass: about 4.87 × 10²⁴ kg.
Atmosphere mainly consists of carbon dioxide (96.5%), nitrogen (3.5%), with trace gases like sulfur dioxide.
Very thick atmosphere causing strong greenhouse effect, resulting in surface temperatures around 470°C.
Average distance from the Sun: about 108.2 million km.
Average distance from Earth: about 41 million km.
Hottest planet in the Solar System with a surface temperature of about 470°C.
Rotates in the opposite direction to most other planets.

name: EARTH
details: Earth is where humans have lived and explored since ancient times, so there is no specific discovery date.
Diameter: about 12,742 km.
Surface area: about 510 million km².
Mass: about 5.97 × 10²⁴ kg.
Atmosphere primarily consists of nitrogen (78%), oxygen (21%), with trace gases like argon and carbon dioxide.
Average distance from the Sun: about 149.6 million km.
The only planet known to support life.
Has one natural satellite, the Moon.

name: MARS
details: Known since ancient times and often called the 'Red Planet' due to its distinctive color.
Diameter: about 6,779 km.
Surface area: about 144 million km².
Mass: about 6.42 × 10²³ kg.
Atmosphere mainly consists of carbon dioxide (95.3%), nitrogen (2.7%), and argon (1.6%).
Average distance from the Sun: about 227.9 million km.
Average distance from Earth: about 54.6 million km.
Called the 'Red Planet' due to iron oxide (rust) on its surface.
Has two small moons: Phobos and Deimos.

name: JUPITER
details: Known since ancient times and considered the largest planet in the Solar System, no specific discovery date.
Diameter: about 139,822 km.
Surface area: about 61.4 million km².
Mass: about 1.90 × 10²⁷ kg.
Atmosphere primarily consists of hydrogen (90%) and helium (10%), with other components like ammonia and methane.
Average distance from the Sun: about 778.5 million km.
Average distance from Earth: about 588 million km.
Largest planet in the Solar System.
Has at least 79 moons, including four large moons known as the Galilean moons: Io, Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto.

name: SATURN
details: Known since ancient times, no specific discovery date.
Famous for its beautiful rings.
Diameter: about 116,464 km.
Surface area: about 42.7 million km².
Mass: about 5.68 × 10²⁶ kg.
Atmosphere primarily consists of hydrogen (96%) and helium (3%), with trace gases like methane.
Average distance from the Sun: about 1.43 billion km.
Average distance from Earth: about 1.2 billion km.
Known for its beautiful rings, mainly made of ice and rock.
Has at least 83 moons, the largest of which is Titan.

name: URANUS
details: Discovered in 1781 by William Herschel, marking it as the first planet found with a telescope.
Diameter: about 50,724 km.
Surface area: about 8.1 million km².
Mass: about 8.68 × 10²⁵ kg.
Atmosphere primarily consists of hydrogen (83%) and helium (15%), along with methane, giving it a blue color.
Average distance from the Sun: about 2.87 billion km.
Average distance from Earth: about 2.57 billion km.
The most tilted planet in the Solar System.
Has at least 27 moons, the largest of which are Titania and Oberon.

name: NEPTUNE
details: Discovered on September 23, 1846 by Johann Galle and Heinrich d'Arrest.
Diameter: about 49,244 km.
Surface area: about 7.6 million km².
Mass: about 1.02 × 10²⁶ kg.
Atmosphere primarily consists of hydrogen (80%), helium (19%), and methane, giving it a deep blue color.
Average distance from the Sun: about 4.5 billion km.
Average distance from Earth: about 4.3 billion km.
Experiences large storms with high wind speeds, reaching up to 2,100 km/h.
Has at least 14 moons, the largest of which is Triton.
